reviews.review_text: Nation Red is a really amazing zombie shooter game in third person perspective.  Pros: + nice design, different maps / locations + playable in singleplayer, coop, multiplayer + different modes (e. g. defending a barricade, survival, king oft he hill, free play) + convenient music, good sound + different survivors with special abilities + all options possible (graphic, audio and so on) + selectable level of difficulty + you can turn friendly fire on/off, collect exp together or alone + a ton of zombies and massive growing waves  + many different weapons which you get by killing the zombies + health kits, short-term skills (also by killing zombies) + levelsystem (you can choose an ability with every new level) + players can resurrect teammates at any time  + 140 achievements to hunt, leaderboards + IT MAKES FUN!  Cons: - no story (in Singleplayer you have missions, but no profound story)  This game is for people who really enjoy using many different weapons, having action all the time, killing non stop zombies without thinking much and without a break. So hm I love the game. lol   Original price: 8,99 € Summersale: 2,24 €

Red Nation is a great game if you have half an hour to an hour to kill in between doing something significant or if you just want to take a break. It's a simple game of point, shoot, powerup and repeat as you mow down hordes of zombines across some relatively generic levels. While the addition of things like 'boss zombies' changes things up a bit, overall the experience is fairly repetative. It's fairly mindless and at times, frantic, which I guess makes it a good game to play if you want to get your mind off of things and just let loose for awhile.

The videogame equivalent of a sorbet; light, easy and good for cleansing your pallette before you move onto the next course. Unpretentious in the way that a basic sorbet can be, unburdened with the task of having to be anything more than what it is. It's not going to something you rave about to friends. It's not going give you a lasting experience that you'll reflect upon later, stroking your chin in contemplative thought as you marvel at the sombre atmosphere and the meditation of What Even Is Life.  Nope. Just honest, dumb sorbet. Zombie sorbet. Served in a top-down shooter.

Normally when I think of zombies I think 'oh no they're going to bore me to death'. Seriously, zombies are the most played-out garbage when it comes to videogames. There are so many and they move slowly and ZZzzzzz it's like zombie game developers give up before they wrote their first line of code.  Nation Red however is one of the few legitimately great zombie games. It's an overhead arena shooter, the closest comparison would be Smash TV. Survival isn't just about gunning down the undead, it's also being able to clear paths to get those necessary powerups. Leveling up allows access to numerous special abilities. Some are plain in their functionality like better armor, while others add firepower (venomous darts, acts of God, random explosions), and still others help develop a player's 'build' (stronger sentry guns, better stats at the cost of extraneous weapons). This is part of what makes this game so maddeningly addictive.   As the game progresses the zombie hordes become stronger, their numbers become overwhelming, and death is eventually little more than a bad button press away. At this point the game becomes immensely satisfying. The mechanics aren't as tight as I would like. Melee in general is very iffy and accidentally picking up a crowbar or an axe is almost as bad as diving right into an explosion. Otherwise I don't have any complaints. Online play and a multitude of modes are also nice additions.  Honestly the only reason I don't play this game all the time is because I still have 200+ other games on my Steam account to try. It's that darn good.  Give Nation Red a shot sometime. This is one of those games that tends to drop to 90% off during Steam sales so you won't be hurting for the cash to afford it.

Every so often I like to come back and play little of Nation Red. As a single player game, it's decent fun and offers a really solid challenge, though sometimes bordering on unfair. However, the random drops help to change things up a little, and you can lock onto a weapon when you find one you like (Steam Hammer, anyone?)  It doesn't have a story, it doesn't really offer anything new after the first 5 minutes, and it doesn't have the greatest visuals or soundtrack... but what it does offer is pure, explosive fun.

A fast-paced arena-style zombie shooter. Great time killer. Fun stuff. Kind of in the same spirit of kill-monty. It may not be for everyone and I'm sure that looking at some gameplay (single or multiplayer) videos will dictate to you whether such is the case for you. I think this is a nice and solid action title for an indie collector to have. Good number of characters, weapons, and modes all well designed and fun to play  The game-altering upgrades make it consistantly enjoyable to slaughter your way through zombies that get progressively harder, and therein more satisfying to avoid death at their hands. As you acquire new upgrades, you yourself will start to feel like a walking, zombie-slaying machine while you spit venomous darts and saw blades passively and friendly explosive strikes rain down on the zeds around you.  One of those titles that makes you want to beat that high score. whether it be a friend's, a stranger's, or just your own.  As far as negative aspects, I will say it can get repetative. It's probably not a game you'll be playing constantly or for more than a couple hours at a time, but I believe you'll be happy to have it at your disposal when the itch returns to slaughter something to cure a brief bout with boredom.  Anyway. I liked it.

If you don't own this game, shame on you. It's the best twin-stick shooter on the market, bar none.   It has several game modes, with at least three of them being an 'endless' mode variant. It features many different weapons, each with varying damage, range, reload times, and clips. You get infinite ammo, mega pickups, and hordes and hordes of zombies to murder brutally.  In most modes, you get to choose 'perks' for every score threshold you reach. Perks range from simple things like increased Armor or faster Reloading, to some crazier things like setting zombies on fire for being near you and causing the Turbine pickup to nom zombies.  There are perks that come in perk tiers to upgrade specific pickups - for example, the Fire Team perk upgrades the Ghost pickup so that your Ghost friend carries a shotgun instead of a pistol. Get both Mirror Image and Fire Team, and you get two shotgun ghosts for the pickup. Upgrade to Strike Team and Wild Bunch... and you get FOUR Auto-shotgun wielding Ghost friends to fight by you for a short time.  This game will keep you on your toes the entire time you play. Good luck reaching the top of the leaderboards - it's doable, but good luck.

The idea if Nation Red is simple. Zombie massacre. You will be dropped on a small map with only on goal: Survive the waves of zombies this game throws at you.  Weapons, grenades health and other fragging options are dropped by killed zombies and ammo is unlimited  on the guns. Ammo is not your concern is this game. While the amount of zombies is low when you start, the amount increases significally and even unlimited ammo will eventually be not enough.  On top of your weaponry, there are several other options to help you. Those will become available when your xp increases. This can be a restore of health, increased chance of certain drops and more. You will have to choose the option  that suits you and the amount of zombies everytime.   The zombie count will be enormous so surviving depends on the choices you make during the game.  If you want massive zombie fragging then you should check this out.

Nation Red is an ultra fast infinite play arena-based shooter providing an exceptional close-quarter battlefield experience. Fight thousands of zombie mutants and their bosses in frantic bloody gameplay while earning close to 100 perks. Fight in Barricade, Survival or Free Play mode. Play On-Line in coop, in single player or in local coop!  August 17, 1977   Scattered groups of zombies infiltrate remote Midwestern towns. Incapable of using tools or weapons, the invaders are resisted until they retreat back into the desert. Special elimination posses are set up to hunt down any of the surviving undead. Six weeks after the squads started their search-and-destroy mission, the last known zombie was shot and killed.  Present-day   Over thirty years had passed when a truck driver traveling down a desolate Arizona road plows into a wall of undead. Before the driver's phone signal went dead, he reported some were carrying guns... They're back and now they are hunting us.

Here is a decent little shoot the zombie/infected up type game. You are given a handful of weapons grenades included , unlimited ammo (the game gets you at reloading) and a handful of traits/abilities you can choose as the game progresses and you level up. The cool part is you don't have to choose these traits/abilities, you can just be johnny kill all and kill them with guns.  The graphics aren't bad at all. It does take on that bland dusky dark look like all 'oh darn what happened to the world' type games.  You have a few characters to choose from and starting weapons which was a nice little patch they added. The user interface has definitely been upgraded, much nicer. The bosses aren't impossible just take a bit of tenderizing. One of the nice parts is coop is pretty cool. You have the chance to rez/heal your partner.  The only gripe is you can get killed off screen. Always hated that...  Worth a buy.
